bibl.title: Letter from Tom D. Spies to Philip Showalter Hench, August 3, 1951

div1.p: Spies informs Hench that the University of Havana would like him to attend the International Congress on Nutrition and Metabolism.

Dear Phil:
div1.p:
This is a formal invitation from the University of Havana for you
and your wife to participate in the International Congress on Nutrition and
Metabolism, which will meet between the 20th and the 26th of January in
Havana, Cuba.

The Cubans have loved you for a long time. They like your warm
personality and they like your interest in Carlos Finlay. Most American
doctors they don't like. Since I have been spending much of my time there
during the past eight years, I have gotten to know them well and, for that
reason, they asked me to inquire of you if you will accept their invitation.
They know that you are invited all over the world and they feel very humble
about asking you to come.

They will take care of your and your wife's room at the Hotel
Nacional, and I am sure that if the Mayo Clinic should desire it, they
would be glad to take care of your travel expenses to and from. They did
not say anything about that to me but they badly want you. They want you
to represent the Mayo Clinic. You are their friend and, at the same time,
you epitomize much that is great about the Mayo Clinic.

The Congress itself, I think, will be the most outstanding thing
in nutrition and metabolism that I have ever heard about. They expect to
have Bill Murphy and he has told me unofficially that he expects to go.
Among others expected are Bob Williams, who, as you know, synthesized vitamin
B1; Glen King, who isolated vitamin C; Henry Sebrell, Director of the National
Institute of Health; Elvehjem, who is the dean of the graduate school at
Wisconsin and who is representing the University of Wisconsin; and C. P.
Loranz, who is General Manager of the Southern Medical Association and who
is representing it. They expect the President of the A.M.A. to be there,
though we have not yet asked him to make a final decision. There will be
a lot of other terribly important people both on the program and as observers.
You and I will have to carry most of the work about metabolism and, of course,
that means you. In selecting the group, they had that in mind.

Not knowing how the Mayo Clinic does things exactly, I wonder if
you have a trip committee or group that passes on these invitations. If so,
will you tell them that this is a formal invitation, which will be followed
by the University of Havana's really formal invitation when they are appraised
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Page 2
August 3, 1951
of the fact that you will consider coming. You know how delicate they are
about embarrassing anybody -- hence, their reason for asking me to ascertain
this bit of information. If I had to say, I feel that the Cubans consider
you more essential than anyone else on the program.

I am leaving for Havana about the 11th or 12th of this month. If
it is convenient, you might send a wire to me in Birmingham, appraising me
what the score might be.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, Tom D. Spies, M. D. TDS:bs
